sentence.text: The female proposita (Fig. 1) was delivered by cesarean at 36 weeks gestation due to breech presentation with normal birth parameters.
A two-vessel umbilical cord, hypertelorism and a wide metopic suture were noted at birth.
Her hearing and newborn metabolic screening tests were unremarkable and she was discharged from the hospital on day 4 of life.
She was referred to Genetics at 5 months for hypertelorism.
Growth and development were normal at that time.
She had a widow's peak, mild frontal bossing and a widened metopic suture.

She had telecanthus and ocular hypertelorism, with an inner canthal distance (ICD) of 3.5 cm (≫97th centile), interpupillary distance (IPD) of 5.2 cm (≫97th centile) and outer canthal distance (OCD) of 8.2 cm (≫97th centile).
The nasal bridge was broad and the nasal tip was bifid.
The philtrum was relatively long and the mouth had slightly downturned corners.
Her neck was normal and there was no chest deformity.
She had a small, dystrophic left fifth toenail, but her digits and nails were otherwise unremarkable.
A cranial ultrasound performed at 2 months of age had shown no abnormalities other than a right choroid plexus cyst and a left ependymal cyst.
Skull radiographs showed no evidence of craniosynostosis and further cranial imaging was declined.
